Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Integral Projection Models for Populations in Varying Environments: Construction and Analysis
Award.AbstractNarration:
All environments are variable and uncertain: some years are hotter, some wetter; predators wax and wane in abundance. How organisms buffer themselves against this variability, and exploit it, are major challenges for ecology. This project will combine new statistical and mathematical theory with long-term data sets on semi-arid plant communities to address two challenges in understanding how variable environments affect populations. The first goal will be to identify which environmental variables most strongly affect plant demographic rates such as survival, growth, and fecundity. This work will draw upon long-term studies on natural communities that provide observations on thousands of individual plants over multiple decades, along with numerous environmental variables that are measured at high spatial and temporal resolution. With so many potential explanatory variables, standard statistical methods for variable selection are unstable and unreliable. This project will combine data mining methods from machine learning techniques with traditional statistical theory to identify important environmental drivers, and build more reliable demographic models. Ecological questions that will be addressed include whether demographic rates respond primarily to resource availability (e.g., soil moisture) versus non-resource variables such as temperature; how environment and competition interact; and how strongly past conditions affect current performance. The empirical data sets will be used to answer these questions and look for generalities across multiple communities. A second goal is to understand the individual mechanisms that underlie effects of environmental variation. For example, if a plant population's growth is most affected by rainfall, is it because many plants die immediately, or because of long-term effects such as decreased life expectancy and smaller size throughout life? To address such questions, statistical methods from discrete-state random process theory will be extended to continuous states (e.g., individual plant size) and varying environments, and applied to the fitted plant demographic models.

An expected transformative outcome from this project will be new methods for demographic modeling and analysis, and much of its broader significance will be the applications of those tools in ecology, conservation biology and invasive species management. Statistical products from this work will be disseminated freely as R code modules that users can adapt to their own study systems. The project will also support the research training and mentoring of a doctoral student in statistics, and a postdoctoral student in quantitative ecology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Understanding the impact of environmental variation on population and community dynamics requires quantitative descriptions of the abiotic drivers of demographic rates. Exactly the same information is needed to predict how changing climate means and variances will alter population viability,
species geographic ranges and abundances and, ultimately, species richness. Such "norms of reaction" to environmental drivers are also the
key to understanding the selective pressures imposed by environmental change. However, deciding which environmental drivers to include in population models remains challenging and answers to questions about the ecological effects of environmental variation are often sensitive to subtle choices made in building models. In addition, the available methods for studying the effects of environmental variation are limited. Our project applied recent advances in mathematical modeling and statistics to advance our understanding of and ability to predict the ecological consequences of environmental variation.

Intellectual Merit

The Utah State University portion of the project focused on two research questions:

1. How can we identify the climate variables that are the most important drivers of temporal variation in plant demographic rates?

2. How does climate variability influence plant population persistence, growth rates and competitive interactions?

Our work on the first research question identified both opportunities and challenges.  The opportunities are new statistical techniques. For example, we showed that machine learning algorithms are practical ways to work with the virtually limitless number of potential environmental covariates that might influence demographic rates. The challenge is that these techniques require longer time series than most ecologists have. We are now working on developing a guide to model selection that will help ecologists identify which approaches are most promising for their objectives. A second finding from our work on environmental drivers is that plants of different sizes often respond differently to year-to-year variation in temperature and precipitation. Not only do small plants tend to respond more strongly than large plants, but in some cases the direction of their response contrasts with large plants. Recognizing the potential for these size-by-climate interactions may enhance our ability to detect and properly model the population-level effects of environmental variation.

Our work on the second research question, about population persistence and coexistence in varying environments, made two important contributions. First, we developed new tools to quantify coexistence mechanisms in a wide variety of empirical applications, without the need for customized, and difficult, mathematical analyses required by the traditional approach. Second, we used these new tools to show that previous work had not considered all potential coexistence mechanisms. The standard approach to quantifying mechanisms can omit the mechanisms that are actually most important in real systems. For example, applying our methods to experimental results on diatom species coexistence under fluctuating temperatures, we found that the dominant coexistence mechanisms are relative nonlinearity in response to temperature, which is not present in the supposedly complete list of coexistence mechanisms. We have also shown, both theoretically and through empirical applications, how our approach can be used on process-defined coexistence mechanisms amenable to direct experimental study in addition to the theoretical mechanisms that were the focus of previous work. This extension has practical importance because many of these mechanisms can be studied using short-term data (even, in some cases, single-time "snapshot" data) rather than requiring long time series of responses to changing environmental conditions.

This research resulting in 7 peer-reviewed journal articles, with 2 more currently in review and 1 in preparation, and 7 presentations at national and international conferences.

Broader Impacts

In addition to the intellectual contributions described above, the USU portion of the project included:
-the training of two postdoctoral researchers in statistical and mathematical modeling;
-the free dissemination to the research community of computer code to implement our new statistical and mathematical analyses.
